article:
A few years after Mom died, Dad showed up for lunch wearing the soft smile that took over his face whenever he was thinking about her.
"I've   _   these," he said, handing me a bag. "She would have wanted you to   _  them."
I opened the bag to find dozens of   _   , each one wrapped  in white tissue paper and bearing Mom's handwritten words: Stone Harbor, N.J.--8-98.
They were pretty   _   , but to Mom, they were evidence of her endlessly magical life.
She was 61 when she collected these shells, already showing   _   of the lung disease that would kill her the next year. We didn't know that then. We just knew something was   _   and Mom needed an adventure. She   _   dinner and a movie. However, two friends and I had   _   ideas. We wanted to take her to Jersey Shore,   _   my working-class mother had been to the ocean only twice. She loved the   _  .
When I called Mom with our   _   , she was sitting on the couch with her dog Amber on her leg. As soon as I said "Jersey Shore", she screamed and Amber   fell onto   the floor. When I told her she'd be able to hear the   _   from her window, she started to cry.
As soon as we got to Stone Harbor, Mom acted like the town mayor  ,    _   everyone as if they were loyal constituents   . And she spent hours collecting shells on the beach. The morning we   _  , I found her photographing every inch of her bedroom. "I don't even want to   _   this," she said.
For a long time, Mom's shells stayed buried in a drawer. Last month, I   _   them. One by one, the shells are finding a   _   place in my home. I put them where I'm   _   to see them. They   _   me to live a life like my mother--who never lost her sense of wonder.
